title-group.article-title: A University–Community Partnership to Advance Research in Practice Settings
title-group.subtitle: The HUB Research Model

article-meta.aff: 1 Buffalo Center for Social Research, School of Social Work, University at Buffalo, Buffalo, NY, USA
2 Hillside Family of Agencies, Rochester, NY, USA

author-notes.corresp: Catherine N. Dulmus, Buffalo Center for Social Research, School of Social Work, University at Buffalo, 221 Parker Hall, Buffalo, NY 14214, USA Email: cdulmus@buffalo.edu

abstract.p: Human service organizations are uniquely positioned, given their scope of practice and access to consumers with the widest range of needs to significantly increase the national capacity for research if they were effectively equipped with the knowledge, skills, and funding to integrate research and development into their ongoing organizational activities. A university–community research partnership is one approach to achieving this goal. This article describes the Hillside/UB (HUB) Research Model, a formal research partnership between Hillside Family of Agencies (HFA) in Rochester, NY and the Buffalo Center for Social Research (BCSR) at the University at Buffalo (UB). The HUB research model combines the practice expertise and research subject access of HFA with the BCSR research expertise and resources to develop collaboratively a vibrant research partnership based on community-based participatory research (CBPR) principles that garners the strengths and assets of both partners to realize a true research to practice and practice to research agenda.

body.p: In the United States, over 119,000 not-for profit human service organizations provide an array of critical services to adults, children, and families (Arnsberger & Grahm, 2010). These families and individuals present with a variety of problems related to mental health, child welfare, emergency, and safety-net services, to name a few. While such organizations are charged with providing a significant proportion of treatment and services needed in the United States, their funding, knowledge base, and structures generally do not include the capacity to effectively integrate emerging and future evidence-based interventions or contribute to the development of new knowledge. This deficit is a major contributing factor to the 17-year delay between the development of new knowledge and its integration into practice settings (Institute of Medicine, 2001). Human service organizations are uniquely positioned though, given their scope of practice and access to consumers with the widest range of needs, to significantly increase the national capacity for research if they were effectively equipped with the knowledge, skills, and funding to integrate research and development into their ongoing organizational activities. A university–community research partnership is one approach to achieving this goal.

sec.title: University–Community Partnerships
sec.p: A university–community partnership combines resources to achieve mutual goals. When the goal is research development and dissemination, a university partner brings to the table a variety of valuable resources including faculty scholars with research and statistical expertise, world class libraries, knowledge dissemination strategies, and doctoral students. This, when combined with the community partner’s practice knowledge including application of interventions in real-world settings, as well as access to research subjects provides a unique opportunity to shape research questions and execute research studies to advance practice to research and research to practice.

A successful and sustainable university–community agency research partnership model though must address the challenges and barriers related to such partnerships (Israel, Schulz, Parker, & Becker, 1998; Metzler et al., 2003). In particular, issues related to a lack of trust and respect between partners (Dockery, 1996; Hatch, Moss, Saran, Presley-Cantrell, & Mallory, 1993; Martin 1996); disparate power and control (Altman, 1995; Barnett, 1993; Buchanan, 1996; Israel, Schurman, & Hugentobler, 1992; Plough & Olafson, 1994); time demand issues (Mittelmark, Hunt, Heath, & Schmid, 1993; Schulz, Israel, Selig, Bayer, & Griffin, 1998; Weiss & Greene, 1992); establishing research priorities (Metzler et al., 2003); funding conflicts (Buchanan, 1996; Plough & Olafson, 1994); conflicts associated with differences related to philosophies, priorities, and values (Buchanan, 1996; Schulz et al., 1998); differences that arise over the priority of task versus process (Buchanan, 1996;Parker, Schulz, Israel, & Hollis, 1998; Plough & Olafson, 1994); and how community is defined that is representative (Green & Kreuter, 1991; Lillie-Blanton & Hoffman, 1995; Parker et al.,1998; Schulz, Parker et al., 1997). Environmental forces such as social, political, economic, institutional, and cultural issues also inhibit successful university–community partnerships including competing university/agency demands (Martin, 1996; Plaut, Landis, & Trevor, 1992); time involved in relationship building (Dockery, 1996; Eisen, 1994); expectations and demands of funding institutions (Green et al., 1995; Whitehead, 1993); larger political and institutional pressures within the agency and/or university (Israel et al., 1998); and impediments that obstruct institutional, community, and social change (Israel et al., 1998). Strategies to address these challenges include: (a) jointly develop operating mission, vision, and core values (Bailey, 1992; Butterfoss, Goodman, & Wandersman, 1993; Himmelman, 1992; Schurman & Israel, 1995;Stringer, 1996; Vega, 1992); (b) agree on a common set of goals and objectives (Clark, Baker, Chawla, & Maru, 1993; Fawcett et al., 1996; Labonte, 1994); (c) adopt a participatory leadership and decision-making process (Krumpfer, Turner, Hopkins, & Librett, 1993; Metzler et al., 2003; Schulz, Israel, Becker, & Hollis, 1997); (d) provide sufficient staff support for the partnership (Cosier & Glennie, 1994; Whitmore, 1994); (e) integrate research expertise (Israel et al., 1992; Singer, 1994); and (f) establish a prior history of working successfully together (Parker et al., 1997, 1998).

Although there have been efforts to advance evidence-based practice (EBP) into community-based organizations (Aarons & Sawitzky, 2006; Abrahamson, 2001; Burns, 2003; Essock et al., 2003; Glisson, 2002; Goldman et al., 2001; Ringeisen & Hoagwood, 2002), there are several challenges and barriers that have limited the dissemination and implementation of EBPs (Drake, Torrey, & McHugo, 2003; Hoagwood, Burnas, Kiser, Ringeisen, & Schoenwald, 2001; Weisz & Jensen, 1999). A functional and effective university–community partnership must therefore successfully address a variety of barriers identified in the literature, as well as by National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH, 1999) that impede the transfer of research to widely adopted clinical practices, including (a) a lack of leadership support at the agency level (Torrey et al., 2001); (b) clinician’s difficulties to embracing a change in practice (Torrey et al., 2001); (c) limited fiscal resources (Goldman et al., 2001); (d) applicability of EBPs to comorbid populations at the consumer level (Drake et al., 2001); (e) clinicians’ finding that research-based advances are often difficult to systematically implement within their settings (NIMH, 1999); (f) common clinical and service system issues rarely have complete answers from science (NIMH, 1999); (g) practitioners’ inability to keep up with the speed of new research developments (NIMH, 1999); (h) consumers and their family member’s difficultly in accessing the latest research-based interventions so that consumer–family demand influence the speed of adoption of new research based treatments (NIMH, 1999); (i) many researchers believing that grant maker’s funding priorities have been generally geared toward less costly studies that are more simplistic and, as a result, may not generalize well to larger populations of consumers seeking treatment in typical mental health settings (NIMH, 1999); and (j) lack of adequate training resources for both professionals and paraprofessionals to gain competence in EBPs (Corrigan, McCracken, & Blaser, 2003; NIMH, 2006).

In addition, organizational culture and climate affect decisions about whether or not EBPs are adopted and implemented within health care agencies (Glisson, 1996; Hemmelgarn, Glisson, & James, 2006). Early diffusion and implementation literature (Nadler & Tushman, 1997; Rogers, 1995; Rousseau, 1997) indicate that any successful adoption of new technology within an organization is as much a social as a technical formula. Hemmelgarn et al. (2006) report that the social context of an organization can result in different approaches to problem solving and influence what types of interventions will be selected and how interventions will be put into regular practice. Subsequently, the climate and culture of an agency and its university partner must be taken into account in the development and implementation of a university–community research partnership model.

sec.title: University–Community Partnership Models
sec.p: A number of partnerships identified among various community partners (e.g., education, health, housing) and universities successfully utilized a community-based participatory research approach (CBPR; Berardi & Donnelly, 1999; Dearry, Colliman, Saint, Fields, & Redd, 1999; Evans, Birchenough, & Fletcher, 2000; Kegler, Malcoe, Lynch, & Whitecrow-Ollis, 2000; McCauley et al., 2001; Wallerstein, 2000; Wing, Grant, Green, & Stewart, 1996). The CBPR model is a collaborative approach that joins together partners with diverse skills, knowledge, and expertise to conduct research involving all key stakeholders (community members, organizational representatives, and researchers). A critical element of CBPR is that it ensures that all groups have equitable input in all aspects of the research process (Israel, Eng, Schulz, & Parker, 2005). The CBPR approach includes nine key principles that have been developed and tested (Israel et al., 1998, 2003, 2005) and have successfully guided the development of a number of effective CBPR partnerships (Metzler et al., 2003; Spoth & Greenberg, 2005; Vasquez, Minkler, & Shepard, 2006; Walsh et al., 2000). The nine key principles are as follows: (a) recognize community as a unit of identity; (b) build on strengths and resources within the community; (c) facilitate a collaborative, equitable partnership in all phases of the research, involving an empowering and power-sharing process that attends to social inequalities; (d) promote colearning and capacity building among all partners; (e) integrate and achieve a balance between knowledge generation and intervention for the mutual benefit of all partners; (f) focus on the local relevance of public health problems and ecological perspectives that attend to the multiple determinants of health (including mental health); (g) involve systems development through a cyclical and interactive process; (h) disseminate results to all partners and involves them in the wider dissemination process; and (i) involve a long-term process and commitment to sustainability.

The CBPR approach recognizes that partners have differing political and social dynamics, competing institutional demands and funding structures, as well as unique cultures and capacity for institutional change. Within this reality, research indicates that CBPR (a) enhances the relevance and usefulness of research findings (Israel et al., 1998); (b) promotes use of research data by all partners involved (Brown, 1995; Cousins, & Earl, 1995; Schensul, 1985; Schulz, Israel et al., 1997); (c) strengthens the research and program development capacity of the partners (Altman, 1995; Green et al., 1995; Schensul, 1985; Schulz et al., 1998; Singer, 1993, 1994); (d) increases the possibility of overcoming a distrust of research (Hatch et al., 1993; Schulz et al., 1997); (e) creates better informed/more effective practice that is guided by theory (Altman, 1995; Schensul, Denelli-Hess, Borreo, Bhavati, 1987); (f) provides additional resources to support a research and development infrastructure for the partnership members (Altman, 1995; Nyden & Wiewel, 1992; Schulz et al., 1997); (g) acknowledges that knowledge gained can be used by all partners involved to direct resources and influence policies that will benefit the community (deKoning & Martin, 1996; Dressler, 1993; Hall, 1992; Himmelman, 1992; Maguire, 1987; Tandon, 1981); and (h) seeks to improve the overall functioning of the involved partners by directly identifying and addressing needs and indirectly increasing all the partners power and control over the research process (deKoning & Martin, 1996; Durie, 1994; Green et al., 1995; Israel, Checkoway, Schulz, & Zimmerman, 1994; Israel & Schurman, 1990; Wallerstein, 1992). CBPR has been an effective approach for academics to partner with communities around research and is an intrical foundation to the HUB Research model.

sec.title: The Research Partners
sec.p: Hillside Family of Agencies (HFA) is the largest family and children’s service agency in Western and Central New York. HFA has been helping children and their families for more than 170 years. The organization employs more than 2,200 staff within 6 affiliate organizations located in 40 sites across 30 New York counties and in Prince George’s County, Maryland. Affiliates of this $140+ million network provide services to children from birth to age 26 in more than 9,000 families each year. HFA’s six affiliates are: Hillside Children’s Center, Hillside Children’s Foundation, Crestwood Children’s Center, Crestwood Children’s Foundation, Hillside Work-Scholarship Connection, and Snell Farm Children’s Center. HFA provides 120 services in 6 major categories including child welfare, mental health, juvenile justice, education, youth development, and developmental disabilities/mental health. HFA holds New York state (NYS) licenses with the Office of Children and Family Services, the Office of Mental Health, the Office for People with Developmental Disabilities (OPWDD), the Department of Health and the State Education Department and is accredited by the Council on Accreditation. In 2007, HFA’s Board of Directors adopted as the agency’s strategic intent to be the leader in translating research into effective practice solutions. This strategic goal specifically aims at connecting research and best practices to benefit the lives of children and families and disseminate HFA’s work to the human service field.

To support this strategic intent, a decision was made to hire a research director. In the summer of 2007, HFA’s Chief Strategy and Quality Officer approached the Buffalo Center for Social Research (BCSR) at the University at Buffalo (UB) for technical assistance in conducting a national search for a research director.

The BCSR is the UB School of Social Work’s (SSW) research center located on the South campus of UB in Buffalo, NY. The BCSR comprises four full-time positions: a director, statistician, grants administrator, and office manager. The BCSR provides technical assistance and support for both UB SSW faculty and students in designing and implementing research projects as well as in securing external funding. Both preaward and postaward services are provided, as well as space accommodation within the 4,000 sq. ft. center for project personnel and data storage. A state-of-the-art data analysis lab is maintained and available to support all projects. In addition, the UB SSW doctoral student offices are located within the BCSR.

The BCSR director provided consultation in both job description and search strategy to HFA and also sat on the interview committee. In 2008, HFA launched a national search for a research director, but it was a failed search as no person who was deemed “bilingual” in both research and practice scopes of knowledge and skill sets were found. Out of the search process, HFA recognized that top flight researchers are connected to research universities and that it would be difficult to recruit one to an agency setting. With this realization, the BCSR director suggested that rather than to develop an internal research department at HFA to support their strategic intent, a better approach might be to design and develop a formal research partnership between HFA and a university. HFA’s Chief Strategy and Quality Officer asked that BCSR put together a proposal. The BCSR director subsequently designed the following Hillside/UB (HUB) model and developed a 5-year budget to support the initial implementation of this community–university research partnership.

sec.title: The HUB Research Model
sec.p: In January 2009, a 5-year contract was signed to implement a collaborative research partnership between BCSR and HFA with an overarching goal for BCSR to assist HFA in establishing and implementing a strategically focused research program that builds on the strengths of both partners. The HUB research model consisted of HFA purchasing from BCSR 50% effort of director (PI), 20% effort of statistician, 10% effort of grants administrator, 5% effort of office manager, 1 PhD student (assistantship, benefits, tuition), as well as supplies, software, and travel costs. The HUB research model design combined the practice expertise and research subject access of HFA with the BCSR research expertise and resources to develop collaboratively a research partnership based on CBPR principles to support HFA’s strategic intent. The purpose was not to develop a research department within HFA but instead to build together an evolving research partnership that garnered the strengths and assets of both partners to realize a true research to practice and practice to research agenda. The contract stated the following initial 5-year intended HUB partnership outcomes:

list-item.p: Formulate relationships with HFA staff, relevant Board Members, and Affiliates.
Conduct an environmental scan to assess HFA’s existing research capacities and infrastructure needs.
Develop, and where appropriate, begin implementing a training plan to assist HFA staff in understanding and supporting the partnership’s research to practice and practice to research priorities.
Develop a collaborative research department including systems, policies, and procedures.
Collaboratively develop a vision statement of what the partnership will look like at the 5-year mark.
Begin a strategic planning process that will achieve the agreed vision.
Develop a mutually agreed upon process to identify HFA research priorities and implement same.
Pending the completion of the strategic planning process, develop, and implement an interim systematic research plan and identify necessary resources to support same.
Provide expert guidance on research to HFA staff and board members.
Match BCSR and national experts to HFA’s research needs.
Begin to establish a regional and national HFA partnership research presence.
Participate in the development of research grant proposals to secure federal and private funding for research studies.
Design and execute an HFA longitudinal study to follow children postdischarge.
Establish the HFA speaker series as a mechanism to engage external experts.
Direct research partnership.
Complete strategic planning process.
Implement strategic plan.
Continue to provide expert guidance on research to HFA staff and board members.
Serve as consultant to HFA leadership.
Continue building a regional and national HFA partnership research presence.
Begin to establish an international HFA partnership research presence.
Partner with senior management to appoint a research advisory council.
Participate in the development of research grant proposals to secure federal and private funding for research studies.
Direct research partnership.
Implement strategic plan.
Continue to provide expert guidance on research to HFA staff and board members.
Continue building a regional, national, and international HFA partnership research presence.
Participate in the development of research grant proposals to secure federal and private funding for research studies.

sec.title: HUB Research Model Evolution and Unintended Outcomes
sec.p:
After 2 years, the research partnership continues strong. All intended outcomes to date as stated in our contract have been achieved, but more important is how the model has evolved and the exciting unintended outcomes that have been realized. What started out as a prescribed partnership that utilized CBPR principles has resulted in a dynamic partnership that allows us to work together in further developing and implementing a powerful model that better meets the needs of both partners. The unintended outcomes to date include:
Survey data collected on over 80% of HFA’s direct care staff (n = 1,273) to assess organizational climate and culture and workforce’s readiness to implement EBPs.
Development of a master of social work (MSW) field unit within the partnership that pairs MSW students as research assistants with doctoral students to conduct program evaluation and research projects.
Development and implementation of a federally registered Institutional Review Board (IRB) at HFA with two UB faculty as members on the IRB.
Eight UB SSW doctoral students involved in various writing and research projects within the partnership at HFA.
Six UB SSW doctoral students conducting community-based dissertations within the partnership at HFA ranging from program evaluations, to intervention development and testing, to randomized controlled studies.
Four UB SSW faculty involved in various research projects and program evaluations.
HUB research collaborations with four other research universities.
Two collaborative grant proposals in development stage.
Six joint manuscripts under review for publication consideration.
HFA’s first international presentation and book chapter publication as products from the HUB partnership.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The HUB research model is a university–community research partnership based on CBPR principles that holds much promise for decreasing the 17-year delay between development of new knowledge and the availability of that knowledge at the practice setting. When researchers and practitioners form a research partnership whereby each are contributing members in the development of research questions, methodological design, data collection and analysis, as well as dissemination of findings everyone benefits in a variety of ways. Subsequently, when you train MSW and doctoral students within the HUB model a new generation of practitioners and scholars is developed with knowledge of CBPR and an understanding and value of community-based research. Potential benefits abound for clients, agencies, universities, and students as outlined below:

list-item.p: The most effective treatments are made available more quickly.
Outcomes can be more readily identified and measured to inform practice.
Applying the most effective treatments and measuring outcomes to inform ongoing practice should result in improved outcomes.
Clients and their families have opportunities to influence research by participating on research teams.
Stronger case for funding programs proven to work.
Developing effective evaluation infrastructure.
Make case for funding research infrastructure.
Employer of choice.
Advancement of mission/strategic intent.
New perspectives and insights.
Rewarding personal and professional relationships.
Access to information and research.
Collaborative research funding opportunities.
Exposure and access to higher education.
Funders and donors recognize the value added of an agency that can create a research and development capacity.
Contributing to the development of new knowledge.
Enhanced relationship with an agency for both students and faculty.
Increased understanding of “real-world” practice issues and concerns.
Enhanced research directions.
New teaching applications.
External funding opportunities.
Transformational learning experiences.
Clarification of values, sense of professional self.
Awareness and understanding of policy issues.
Awareness and understanding of broader health and social justice issues.
Learning to work as part of a research team.
Leadership development.
Potential opportunities for employment.

sec.title: Future Directions
sec.p: As we begin the third year of the partnership, we have been urged by many colleagues across the country to share the HUB research model. We are doing so at this time as we believe strongly that university–community research partnerships hold much promise for the development and implementation of EBPs in real-world settings. It is our belief that such partnerships when built on CBPR principles allow for both partners to fully share their unique contributions to the partnership and to ultimately learn from one another to better promote research to practice and practice to research.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
